CA1510.fullDescription: Throw helpers are simpler and more efficient than an if block constructing a new exception instance.

CA1822.fullDescription: Members that do not access instance data or call instance methods can be marked as static. After you mark the methods as static, the compiler will emit nonvirtual call sites to these members. This can give you a measurable performance gain for performance-sensitive code.

CA1860.fullDescription: Prefer using 'IsEmpty', 'Count' or 'Length' properties whichever available, rather than calling 'Enumerable.Any()'. The intent is clearer and it is more performant than using 'Enumerable.Any()' extension method.

S107.shortDescription: Methods should not have too many parameters
S107.fullDescription: Methods with a long parameter list are difficult to use because maintainers must figure out the role of each parameter and keep track of their position.

S109.shortDescription: Magic numbers should not be used
S109.fullDescription: A magic number is a hard-coded numerical value that may lack context or meaning. They should not be used because they can make the code less readable and maintainable.

S1128.fullDescription: Unnecessary using directives refer to importing namespaces, types or creating aliases that are not used or referenced anywhere in the code.

S113.shortDescription: Files should end with a newline
S113.fullDescription: Some tools work better when files end with an empty line.

S1144.shortDescription: Unused private types or members should be removed
S1144.fullDescription: This rule raises an issue when a private/internal type or member is never referenced in the code.

S1151.shortDescription: "switch case" clauses should not have too many lines of code
S1151.fullDescription: The switch statement should be used only to clearly define some new branches in the control flow. As soon as a case clause contains too many statements this highly decreases the readability of the overall control flow statement. In such case, the content of the case clause should be extracted into a dedicated method.

S1192.shortDescription: String literals should not be duplicated
S1192.fullDescription: Duplicated string literals make the process of refactoring complex and error-prone, as any change would need to be propagated on all occurrences.

S121.shortDescription: Control structures should use curly braces
S121.fullDescription: Control structures are code statements that impact the programs control flow (e.g., if statements, for loops, etc.)

S122.shortDescription: Statements should be on separate lines
S122.fullDescription: Putting multiple statements on a single line lowers the code readability and makes debugging the code more complex.

S126.shortDescription: "if ... else if" constructs should end with "else" clauses
S126.fullDescription: This rule applies whenever an if statement is followed by one or more else if statements; the final else if should be followed by an else statement.

S131.shortDescription: "switch/Select" statements should contain a "default/Case Else" clauses
S131.fullDescription: The requirement for a final default clause is defensive programming. The clause should either take appropriate action, or contain a suitable comment as to why no action is taken. Even when the switch covers all current values of an enum, a default case should still be used because there is no guarantee that the enum wont be extended.

S1451.shortDescription: Track lack of copyright and license headers
S1451.fullDescription: Each source file should start with a header stating file ownership and the license which must be used to distribute the application.

S1541.shortDescription: Methods and properties should not be too complex
S1541.fullDescription: The cyclomatic complexity of methods and properties should not exceed a defined threshold. Complex code can perform poorly and will in any case be difficult to understand and therefore to maintain.

S2302.fullDescription: Because parameter names could be changed during refactoring, they should not be spelled out literally in strings. Instead, use nameof(), and the string thats output will always be correct.

S2325.shortDescription: Methods and properties that don't access instance data should be static
S2325.fullDescription: Methods and properties that dont access instance data should be marked as static for the following reasons:

S2342.shortDescription: Enumeration types should comply with a naming convention
S2342.fullDescription: Shared naming conventions allow teams to collaborate efficiently. This rule checks that all enum names match a provided regular expression.

S2360.shortDescription: Optional parameters should not be used
S2360.fullDescription: The overloading mechanism should be used in place of optional parameters for several reasons:

S3011.shortDescription: Reflection should not be used to increase accessibility of classes, methods, or fields
S3011.fullDescription: Altering or bypassing the accessibility of classes, methods, or fields through reflection violates the encapsulation principle. This can break the internal contracts of the accessed target and lead to maintainability issues and runtime errors.

S3052.shortDescription: Members should not be initialized to default values
S3052.fullDescription: The compiler automatically initializes class fields, auto-properties and events to their default values before setting them with any initialization values, so there is no need to explicitly set a member to its default value. Further, under the logic that cleaner code is better code, its considered poor style to do so.

S3240.shortDescription: The simplest possible condition syntax should be used
S3240.fullDescription: In the interests of keeping code clean, the simplest possible conditional syntax should be used. That means

S3253.shortDescription: Constructor and destructor declarations should not be redundant
S3253.fullDescription: Since the compiler will automatically invoke the base types no-argument constructor, theres no need to specify its invocation explicitly. Also, when only a single public parameterless constructor is defined in a class, then that constructor can be removed because the compiler would generate it automatically. Similarly, empty static constructors and empty destructors are also wasted keystrokes.

S3254.shortDescription: Default parameter values should not be passed as arguments
S3254.fullDescription: Specifying the default parameter values in a method call is redundant. Such values should be omitted in the interests of readability.

S3267.shortDescription: Loops should be simplified with "LINQ" expressions
S3267.fullDescription: Using explicit loops for filtering, selecting, or aggregating elements can make code more verbose and harder to read. LINQ expressions provide a more concise and expressive way to perform these operations, improving code clarity and maintainability.

S3604.shortDescription: Member initializer values should not be redundant
S3604.fullDescription: Fields, properties and events can be initialized either inline or in the constructor. Initializing them inline and in the constructor at the same time is redundant; the inline initialization will be overridden.

S3877.shortDescription: Exceptions should not be thrown from unexpected methods
S3877.fullDescription: The rule is reporting when an exception is thrown from certain methods and constructors. These methods are expected to behave in a specific way and throwing an exception from them can lead to unexpected behavior and break the calling code.

S3956.shortDescription: "Generic.List" instances should not be part of public APIs
S3956.fullDescription: System.Collections.Generic.List<T> is a generic collection that is designed for performance and not inheritance. For example, it does not contain virtual members that make it easier to change the behavior of an inherited class. That means that future attempts to expand the behavior will be spoiled because the extension points simply arent there. Instead, one of the following generic collections should be used:

S3990.shortDescription: Assemblies should be marked as CLS compliant
S3990.fullDescription: Assemblies should conform with the Common Language Specification (CLS) in order to be usable across programming languages. To be compliant an assembly has to indicate it with System.CLSCompliantAttribute.

S3992.shortDescription: Assemblies should explicitly specify COM visibility
S3992.fullDescription: Assemblies should explicitly indicate whether they are meant to be COM visible or not. If the ComVisibleAttribute is not present, the default is to make the content of the assembly visible to COM clients.

S3994.shortDescription: URI Parameters should not be strings
S3994.fullDescription: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred. At minimum, an overload of the method taking a System.Uri as a parameter should be provided in each class that contains a method with an apparent Uri passed as a string.

S3996.shortDescription: URI properties should not be strings
S3996.fullDescription: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred.

S4004.fullDescription: A writable collection property can be replaced by a completely different collection. Making it readonly prevents that while still allowing individual members to be set. If you want to allow the replacement of the whole collection the recommended pattern is to implement a method to remove all the elements (e.g. System.Collections.List<T>.Clear) and a method to populate the collection (e.g. System.Collections.List<T>.AddRange).

S4027.fullDescription: Exceptions types should provide the following constructors:

S4049.fullDescription: Properties are accessed like fields which makes them easier to use.

S4056.shortDescription: Overloads with a "CultureInfo" or an "IFormatProvider" parameter should be used
S4056.fullDescription: When a System.Globalization.CultureInfo or IFormatProvider object is not supplied, the default value that is supplied by the overloaded member might not have the effect that you want in all locales.

S4069.shortDescription: Operator overloads should have named alternatives
S4069.fullDescription: Operator overloading is convenient but unfortunately not portable across languages. To be able to access the same functionality from another language you need to provide an alternate named method following the convention:

S6354.fullDescription: One of the principles of a unit test is that it must have full control of the system under test. This is problematic when production code includes calls to static methods, which cannot be changed or controlled. Date/time functions are usually provided by system libraries as static methods.

S6563.shortDescription: Use UTC when recording DateTime instants
S6563.fullDescription: You should avoid recording time instants with the use of property DateTime.Now. The property DateTime.Now returns the current date and time expressed in the machines local time without containing any timezone-related information (for example, the offset from Coordinated Universal Time). Not having this information means that if you need to display this DateTime object or use it for computations in another machine placed in a different time zone, you wont be able to reconstruct it in the second machines local time without knowing the origins offset. This will likely lead to confusion and potential bugs.

S6566.fullDescription: This rule recommends using DateTimeOffset instead of DateTime for projects targeting .NET Framework 2.0 or later.

S6602.shortDescription: "Find" method should be used instead of the "FirstOrDefault" extension
S6602.fullDescription: Both the List.Find method and the Enumerable.FirstOrDefault method can be used to locate the first element that meets a specified condition within a collection. However, for List objects, List.Find may offer superior performance compared to Enumerable.FirstOrDefault. While the performance difference might be negligible for small collections, it can become significant for larger collections. This observation also holds true for ImmutableList and arrays.

S6605.shortDescription: Collection-specific "Exists" method should be used instead of the "Any" extension
S6605.fullDescription: Both the List.Exists method and IEnumerable.Any method can be used to find the first element that satisfies a predicate in a collection. However, List.Exists can be faster than IEnumerable.Any for List objects, as well as requires significantly less memory. For small collections, the performance difference may be negligible, but for large collections, it can be noticeable. The same applies to ImmutableList and arrays too.
